tool.name: AquaINFRA OGC API Processes

param.name: select_process
param.label: Select process
param.option: peri-conv: Group data to groups based on date
ts-selection-interpolation: Select and Interpolate Time Series
trend-analysis-mk: Man-Kendall Trend Analysis on Time Series
barplot-trend-results: Visualisation of statistical analysis results
map-trends-static: Spatial visualisation of regions and data points
map-shapefile-points: Spatial visualisation of regions and data points
tordera-gloria: SWAT+, Soil and Water Assessment Tool
tordera-gloria-connection: SWAT+ output to MITgcm input connection tool
retrieve-biodiversity-data: Retrieve biodiversity data from the web
match-data: Combine and match biodiversity data from separate sources
check-names: Check species names in biodiversity data from separate sources
pred-extract: pred extract for extraction of environmnetal data
multidetect-and-clean: Run multidetect and clean the data

param.name: input_data
param.label: Table to be merged with study region
param.help: URL to the input table containing the in-situ data points with coordinates. Can be provided as Excel file or CSV file (comma-separated text file). The coordinates have to be in WGS84 coordinate system. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: regions
param.label: Study region or study subregions
param.help: URL to the study region, or several regions, to classify your input data into groups of interest. Currently it has to be provided as a shapefile. It can be in any coordinate system and will be transformed to WGS84 during this process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_long
param.label: Column name for longitude
param.help: Only needed for data other than geojson. Name of the column that contains longitude values (in WGS84).

param.name: colname_lat
param.label: Column name for latiitude
param.help: Only needed for data other than geojson. Name of the column that contains latitude values (in WGS84).

param.name: input_data
param.label: Table to be grouped by date, with date colum
param.help: URL to the table with a column containing a date. It can have other columns which will not be changed during this process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_date
param.label: Date column name
param.help: Column name of the date column in the format defined above. Example: 'visit_date'.

param.name: date_format
param.label: Date format
param.help: The date format used to parse the date, i.e. to extract day, month and year from the date column, e.g. or 'y-m-d' for dates like '1998-08-22' (this is the default) or 'y/m/d' for dates like '1998/08/22'.

param.name: group_to_periods
param.label: Periods to group the data into
param.help: Define the periods that you want the data to be grouped into. Please follow the example (which is also the default): 'Dec-01:Mar-01,Mar-02:May-30,Jun-01:Aug-30,Sep-01:Nov-30' (first three letters of each month, then a minus/hyphen, then the day (two digits), then comma, then the next period).

param.name: period_labels
param.label: Period labels
param.help: Define names for the periods defined above, separated by a comma. Example (which is also the default): 'winter,spring,summer,autumn'.

param.name: year_starts_at_dec1
param.label: Include December into next year
param.help: Tell whether the years in your grouping starts at first of December ('true') or not ('false'). This has to be reflected in the period definitions, these should not contradict each other. Defaults to 'true'.

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing group identifier(s) and a value column. Groups are defined by one or more columns. Other columns present in the table will be removed in the process, retaining only those specified in cols_to_group_by and value_col. For example, use the result table from peri_conv. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colnames_to_group_by
param.label: Column names identifying group
param.help: One or more column names identifying the group. A combination of all specified columns will be used to define unique groups for calculating the average value. Example: 'longitude, latitude, Year_adj_generated, group_labels, HELCOM_ID'. Another example: 'Year_adj_generated, group_labels, HELCOM_ID'.

param.name: colname_value
param.label: Column name for column containing values
param.help: The name of the column that contains the values for which the average will be calculated. Only one column name can be included. Examples: 'transparency_m', 'mean'

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing data for selection and interpolation. This table includes grouping variables (if applicable), the year (or other time identifier) and the value columns to be interpolated. For example, use the result from mean_by_group. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colnames_relevant
param.label: Column names identifying group(s)
param.help: Column name(s) describing relevant values in the dataset. These columns are treated as grouping identifiers, and a combination of all specified columns will be used to define unique groups. For each group, a separate time series is analyzed and interpolated individually.

param.name: missing_threshold_percentage
param.label: Threshold for missing values
param.help: Threshold for the allowed percentage of missing data points (NAs). For example, a value of 80 means series with more than 80% missing data will be removed. Example = '80'.

param.name: colname_year
param.label: Column name for time
param.help: The name of the column containing the year (or other time identifier, such as quarter, month, or day). Example = 'year'

param.name: colname_value
param.label: Column name for values
param.help: The name of the column containing the values to be considered for interpolation.

param.name: min_data_point
param.label: Minimum number of data points required
param.help: The minimum number of data points required in a time series for it to be included in the interpolation process. Example = '10'.

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing the time series data. This table includes grouping identifiers (if applicable), columns for time (e.g., year, month) and values to be analyzed for trends. For example, use the result from ts_selection_interpolation. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colnames_relevant
param.label: Column names identifying group(s)
param.help: Column name(s) identifying relevant groups in the dataset. These columns will be used to define unique groups for which separate trend analyses are performed.

param.name: colname_time
param.label: Column name for time
param.help: The name of the column containing the time variable (e.g., year, month) to be used in the trend analysis. Example = 'year'.

param.name: colname_value
param.label: Column name for values
param.help: The name of the column containing the values to be analyzed in the Man-Kendall trend test.

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing statistical analysis results. The table must include columns for test values, p-values, and group identifiers. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_id
param.label: Column name for identifier
param.help: The name of the column containing group or sample identifiers, e.g., polygon id. Example = 'polygon_id'

param.name: colname_test_value
param.label: Column name for test value
param.help: The name of the column containing the test values (e.g., statistical coefficients) to be plotted on the Y-axis, e.g., Tau for Mann-Kendall test.

param.name: colname_p_value
param.label: Column name for p value
param.help: The name of the column containing p values, used to determine bar transparency. Example = 'p_value'

param.name: p_value_threshold
param.label: p value threshold for significance
param.help: The threshold for distinguishing significant from insignificant values. It adjusts the transparency of bars in the plot. Example = '0.05'

param.name: colname_group
param.label: Column name for subgroups
param.help: The name of the column that defines the subgroups or categories to be displayed on the X-axis, e.g., seasons for every polygon_id.

param.name: regions
param.label: Study region or study subregions
param.help: URL to the study region, or several regions, used to classify the input data into groups of interest. Currently it has to be provided as a shapefile. It can be in any coordinate system and will be transformed to WGS84 during this process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing statistical analysis results. The table must include columns for test values, p-values, and identifiers linking to study region. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_id_trend
param.label: Column name of study region identifier
param.help: The name of the column containing identifiers for study regions, which must correspond to the identifiers in the shapefile (shp). Example = 'id'

param.name: colname_region_id
param.label: Column name of study region identifier
param.help: The name of the column in the input data that contains identifiers for study regions, corresponding to the identifiers in the shapefile. Example = 'id'

param.name: colname_group
param.label: Column name for subgroups
param.help: The name of the column that defines the subgroups or categories to be displayed on the X-axis, e.g., seasons for every polygon_id.

param.name: p_value_threshold
param.label: p value threshold for significance
param.help: The threshold for distinguishing significant from insignificant values. It adjusts the transparency of bars in the plot. Default = 0.05

param.name: colname_p_value
param.label: Column name for p value
param.help: The name of the column containing p values, used to determine bar transparency. Example = 'p_value'

param.name: regions
param.label: Study region or study subregions
param.help: URL to the study region, or several regions, to classify the input data into groups of interest. Currently it has to be provided as a shapefile. It can be in any coordinate system and will be transformed to WGS84 during this process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: input_data
param.label: Data table to be plotted on top of study regions
param.help: URL to the input table containing the in-situ data points with coordinates. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_long
param.label: Column name for longitude
param.help: The name of the column containing longitude values for the data points.

param.name: colname_lat
param.label: Column name for latitude
param.help: The name of the column containing latitude values for the data points.

param.name: colname_value_name
param.label: Column name of data point identifier
param.help: The name of the column containing identifier (e.g., site name) or values (e.g., depth) to color the points according to their corresponding values.

param.name: colname_region_id
param.label: Column name of region identifier
param.help: The name of the column containing identifiers (e.g., basin name) to distinguish the polygons on the map if multiple regions are present.

param.name: input_data_url
param.label: Input data
param.help: URL to your input file. Find example data on https://github.com/bishun945/pyOWT/tree/main/projects/AquaINFRA. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: input_option
param.label: Type of input
param.help: csv: for text data input (first line wavelength, following lines remote-sensing reflectance). sat: for satellite product input containing reflectance (e.g., Sentinel-3 OLCI Level-2)

param.name: sensor
param.label: Sensor name
param.help: Spectral band configuration of satellite mission (includes adaptation to sensor spectral response functions).

param.name: output_option
param.label: Output option
param.help: 1: for standard output with five variables. 2: for extensive output including memberships of all water types.

param.name: TextInOut_URL
param.label: URL to project folder
param.help: To model a watershed other than the Tordera Basin, users can add a URL to their own zipped project folder. Important: Do not include the SWAT executable to that folder â€” AquaINFRA has integrated the executable version rev60.5.7_64rel_linux. Defaults to: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AmandaBatlle/AquaINFRA_CaseUse_MedInlandModel/refs/heads/main/example_inputs/project.zip

param.name: par_cal
param.label: Parameter inputs
param.help: JSON file including the parameter value change as defined by SWATrunR documentation (https://chrisschuerz.github.io/SWATrunR/articles/SWATrunR.html#parameter-inputs). Defaults to: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AmandaBatlle/AquaINFRA_CaseUse_MedInlandModel/refs/heads/main/example_inputs/par_cal.json

param.name: unit
param.label: Output Spatial unit
param.help: Specify the spatial unit for which to generate output. This corresponds to the ID of a river reach, HRU (Hydrologic Response Unit), or LSU (Landscape Unit) as defined in the SWAT+ watershed delineation. The value can be entered as a single number (e.g., 1), a range (e.g., 1:10), or a list of values (e.g., (1, 3, 25, 40)). The default unit for the La Tordera SWAT+ model is 1.

param.name: file
param.label: SWAT Output File
param.help: A SWAT+ output file name consists of three elements separated by underscores (_): spatial unit, output category, and time step. For example, 'channel_sd_day'. The spatial unit defines the scale of the output and can be basin, hru, lsunit, channel, aquifer, or reservoir. The output category specifies the type of data such as wb (water balance), nb (nutrient balance), ls (losses), pw (plant and weather), or sd (streamflow and sediment in channels). The time step indicates the temporal resolution and can be day (daily), mon (monthly), yr (yearly), or aa (annual average). Combining these elements forms the output file name. For more details, refer to the SWAT+ OUTPUT FILES section in the SWAT+ documentation (https://swatplus.gitbook.io/io-docs). Defaults to: 'channel_sd_day'

param.name: variable
param.label: SWAT Variable
param.help: Variable to simulate. Example: 'flo_out'. For more details and extended capabilities, refer to the SWAT+ OUTPUT FILES section in the SWAT+ documentation (https://swatplus.gitbook.io/io-docs). For one variable, enter the variable name. For multiple variables, enter them separated by comma. Defaults to: 'flo_out,water_temp'

param.name: start_date
param.label: Start Date
param.help: Start date of the simulation in the format yyyymmdd. Defaults to: 20160101. Earliest possible date for the default input project: 20000101.

param.name: start_date_print
param.label: Start Date for printing
param.help: Start date for printing in the format yyyymmdd. Defaults to: 20190601. Earliest possible date for the default input project: 20020101. It is recommended to allow for at least two warm-up years between the model simulation start and the model output printing to ensure relevant results.

param.name: end_date
param.label: End Date
param.help: End date of the simulation in the format yyyymmdd. Defaults to: 20201231. Latest possible date for the default input project: 20221231.

param.name: swat_output_file
param.label: SWAT+ Variable Outputs Database
param.help: SQLite database (thread_1.sqlite) storing the simulated output values based on the defined time range and time step (daily, monthly, yearly, or annual average).

param.name: input_toc_urls
param.label: Input Total Organic Carbon (TOC)
param.help: URL to in situ Total Organic Carbon (TOC) data (date, value). If the data is divided into parts, please provide several URLs separated by a comma. All URLs need to start with http(s). (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: input_discharge_urls
param.label: Input discharge
param.help: URL to the daily discharge data (date, value). If the data is divided into parts, please provide several URLs separated by a comma. All URLs need to start with http(s). (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: netcdf_input_file
param.label: NetCDF input file
param.help: The NetCDF input file that should be plotted. It must comply to some specific properties with respect to variables. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: variable
param.label: Variable to be plotted
param.help: The variable that should be plotted. You can choose between 'T', 'S', 'U', 'V', 'Eta' and 'W'.

param.name: plot_time
param.label: Hour to be plotted
param.help: The time of day (hourly resolution) that should be plotted. Please specify it in this specific format: '20220703-12:00:00'. We assume that the hour is in the simulation period.

validator.message: You must specify the hour to be plotted.

param.name: plot_depth
param.label: Depth to be plotted
param.help: The depth at which should be plotted. The plot will be at the closest vertical level to this depth. Please specify a negative value. We assume the depth is in the range of our depths.

param.name: min_var_for_color
param.label: Minimum value to be considered for color limit
param.help: This is a parameter controlling the color limits to display. Example (for salinity): 35. Leave empty to let the color limits be chosen automatically.

param.name: max_var_for_color
param.label: Maximum value to be considered for color limit
param.help: This is a parameter controlling the color limits to display. Example (for salinity): 38. Leave empty to let the color limits be chosen automatically.

param.name: species_names_list
param.label: Species names to download (list of species)
param.help: List of species. If you have a url to the dataset, use the option below.

param.name: species_names_url
param.label: Data with species names to download
param.help: URL to a table containing the occurrences from any source. This can be the outcome of the matchdata process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_species
param.label: Species column name
param.help: If the data provided in the data path is a dataframe, indicate here the column name with species names.

param.name: databases_array
param.label: Database names
param.help: List of databases to consider. Only 'gbif, inat, vertnet' supported.

param.name: gbif_limit
param.label: Max number (GBIF)
param.help: The maximum number of data points that are being retrieved from GBIF.

param.name: inaturalist_limit
param.label: Max number (iNaturalist)
param.help: The maximum number of data points that are being retrieved from iNaturalist.

param.name: vertnet_limit
param.label: Max number (VertNet)
param.help: The maximum number of data points that are being retrieved from VertNet.

param.name: study_area_bbox_object
param.label: Area of Interest as a bounding box
param.help: A bounding box: {'bbox': [south, west, north, east]} (see https://docs.ogc.org/is/18-062r2/18-062r2.html#bounding-box-value)

param.name: study_area_shapefile
param.label: Area of Interest as shapefile
param.help: URL to the zipped input shapefile containing the study areas inside which you would like to retrieve occurrences. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: study_area_geojson_url
param.label: Area of Interest as GeoJSON
param.help: URL to the input GeoJSON file containing the study areas inside which you would like to retrieve occurrences. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: study_area_geojson_object
param.label: Area of Interest as a GeoJSON object
param.help: Directly post the GeoJSON containing the study areas inside which you would like to retrieve occurrences.

param.name: percentage_correctness
param.label: Species name correctness in percent.
param.help: An number indicating the percentage of species name correctness that should be allowed to be replaced. High values ensure a perfect match from the standard database.

param.name: synonym_check
param.label: Consider synonyms from standard databases like FishBase
param.help: YES, if synoymns species names should be returned from FishBase during data checks before data download.

param.name: input_datasets
param.label: Occurrence data (GBIF, iNaturalist, VertNet, or from any other source)
param.help: URL to CSV tables containing the occurrences from GBIF, iNaturalist and VertNet. This can be the outcome of the retreive biodiversity data process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colnames_species_names_array
param.label: Column names including species names
param.help: List of column names that indicate the Species Name in each of the provided datasets. Example: 'speciesname, scientificName'

param.name: colnames_countries_array
param.label: Column names including country
param.help: List of column names that indicate the Country in each of the provided datasets. Example: 'JDS4_sampling_ID'

param.name: colnames_lat_array
param.label: Column names including Latitude
param.help: List of column names that indicate the Latitude in each of the provided datasets. Example: 'lat, latitude'

param.name: colnames_lon_array
param.label: Column names including Longitude
param.help: List of column names that indicate the Longitude in each of the provided datasets. Example: 'lon, long, longitude'

param.name: colnames_date_array
param.label: Column names including Dates
param.help: List of column names that indicate the dates in each of the provided datasets. Example: 'Date, sampling_date'

param.name: species_names_list
param.label: Species names (List of species)
param.help: List of species names to check from the standard database (FishBase).

param.name: species_names_url
param.label: Species names to check
param.help: URL to a table containing the occurrences from any source. This can be the outcome of the match-data process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_species
param.label: Column name including species names
param.help: Column name that indicate the Species in the provided dataset. Only required you provide tabular occurrence data. Example: 'species'

param.name: percent_correctness
param.label: Species name correctness in percent
param.help: An number indicating the percentage of species name correctness that should be allowed to be replaced. High values ensure a perfect match from the standard database.

param.name: bool_merge
param.label: Merge checked species names on the dataset
param.help: If a dataframe with species names is provided and this is YES, then all columns are returned. For only one species, the merge will be set automatically to false.

param.name: bool_synonym
param.label: Synonym checks
param.help: Return synonym checks from FishBase.

param.name: bool_ecosystem_type
param.label: Output ecosytem types
param.help: Return ecoystem checks for species from FishBase including marine, freshwater, and brackish.

param.name: bool_rm_duplicates
param.label: Remove duplicates
param.help: Remove duplicates from the dataset. Default is FALSE.

param.name: input_data
param.label: Occurrence data
param.help: URL to a table containing the occurrences from any source. This can be the outcome of the check-names process. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: input_raster_url_or_name
param.label: Input raster
param.help: URL of a cloud-optimized raster to be used (will not be downloaded but accessed remotely), or the name of one of the static rasters on the server. Currently only worldclim is available, for testing purposes.

param.name: study_area_extent
param.label: Area of Interest as a Shapefile
param.help: URL to the input shapefile containing the study areas inside which you would like to delineate the bounding box or extent for study area. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: study_area_geojson_url
param.label: Area of Interest as a GeoJSON
param.help: URL to the input GeoJSON file containing the study areas inside which you would like to delineate the bounding box or extent for study area. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: study_area_geojson_object
param.label: Area of Interest as GeoJSON object
param.help: Directly post the GeoJSON containing the study areas inside which you would like to delineate the bounding box or extent for study area.

param.name: colname_lat
param.label: Column name including Latitude
param.help: Column name lat. Example: 'decimalLatitude'

param.name: colname_lon
param.label: Column name including Longitude
param.help: Column name lon. Example: 'decimalLongitude'

param.name: colname_species
param.label: Column name including Species
param.help: Column name species. Example: 'speciescheck'

param.name: mininmum_sprecords
param.label: Minimum points to consider from the species dataset
param.help: The minimum number of points in a dataset to allow species retained in the dataset. Example: 10, is species dataset is less than 10 records will be ignored.

param.name: bool_merge
param.label: Merge extracted data
param.help: This allows to return the full dataset with merged with extracted data.

param.name: bool_list
param.label: Return a list of dataframe for species if they are more than 1
param.help: For multiple species, if set to TRUE, then a list of species dataframes are returned. If false, then a dataframe is returned.

param.name: bool_coords
param.label: Attach the original coordinates
param.help: If YES, the original records used for data extraction will be attached on the dataset. Easy to tract the slight changes in coordinates during data extraction.

param.name: bool_remove_nas
param.label: Remove NAs after data extraction
param.help: If YES, the NAs created when the coordinates did not retrun records and left in the dataset. Default TRUE

param.name: bool_remove_duplicates
param.label: Remove duplicates
param.help: If TRUE, duplicates records will be removed. Default TRUE

param.name: minimum_sprecordsallow
param.label: Minimum species records to consider before using data in species dsitribution modeling
param.help: In species distribution models, species with fewer records needs to be removed but normal data extraction this parameter should be set to FALSE to retain all species.

param.name: input_data
param.label: Input table
param.help: URL to the input table containing the data to be cleaned from outliers: Data sets for multiple or single species from pred_extract and other sources. (URL must be stored in a .txt file)

param.name: colname_variable
param.label: Variable of interest
param.help: Column name identifying the variable of interest where outliers will be checked from for univariate outlier detection methods such as Z-score, mixed interquantile range, reverse jackknifing

param.name: select_columns
param.label: Specify columns to be checked
param.help: In a multivariate dataset, if only particular columns needs to be checked then they should be indicated here. Otherwise all columns will be considerd in outlier detection.

param.name: multiple_species
param.label: Distinguish between multiple species
param.help: If NO, then only a single species dataset is expected.

param.name: output_type
param.label: Output type
param.help: Set whether you want to return outliers or clean dataset. Example outlier.

param.name: group_colname
param.label: Column name including group names
param.help: For multiple groups in a dataframe, provide the column name containing the groups to be checked. For example, a column name with species name in a dataset.

param.name: colname_exclude
param.label: Column names to exclude
param.help: Exclude mainly numerical variables that are not necessary in the analysis, for example x and y columns or latitude/longitude, row numbers or serial IDs. Categorical variables are removed automatically in the data preparation.

param.name: methods
param.label: Outlier detection methods
param.help: The name of methods for Outlier detection to be used, as a comma-separated string. Example = 'mixediqr, logboxplot, iqr, distboxplot, jknife, semiqr, hampel, iforest, lof, mahal'.

param.name: silence_true_errors
param.label: Silence methods that geuninely fail during outlier detection
param.help: If YES, Silence errors for methods that genuinely druing the outlier detection process but continue without breaking other methods.

param.name: boot_run
param.label: Bootstrapping execution
param.help: If set to YES, then bootstrapping will be done for small samples.

param.name: boot_maxrecords
param.label: Maximum records to intiate bootstrapping
param.help: The user can adjust the maximum records were to be be bootstrapped. Default is 30.

param.name: number_of_boots
param.label: Number of bootstraps
param.help: The number of bootstraps to generate during bootstrapping. The default is 10.

param.name: setseed
param.label: Set seed
param.help: Durring bootstrapping, random samples are generated that requires to set a seed for reproducibility.

param.name: boot_threshold
param.label: Threshold value to flag a record from bootstrap samples
param.help: As a record is flagged in multiple bootstrap samples, a threshold is required to extract an outlier. Default is 0.6, meaning if a record is flagged 6 of the 10 bootsraps, will be flagged as an outlier.

param.name: exceute_pca
param.label: Execute Principal Component Analysis
param.help: If true, then PCA will be intiated.

param.name: number_of_pca
param.label: Number of principal components to retain
param.help: The user can indicate the maximum number of principal components to retain in the outlier detection. The Default is 5.

param.name: pca_silence
param.label: Hide messages during PCA analysis
param.help: Messages during PCA analyis are returned if set to NO. Default is YES to silence the messages like the variance explained from the total PCs selected.

param.name: pcavariable
param.label: Select the principal component among the PCs retained to be used as variable of interest
param.help: PC1 is the default variable selected for outlier detection. Other PC2 can can also be set. PC1 is advisable.

param.name: sdm_data
param.label: Change the outlier detection routine based on data type
param.help: If it is univariate data then, set to NO. All data that requires multivariate analysis such as using kmeans, isolation forest, set to YES. Default is YES.

param.name: inform_na_outlier
param.label: Hide messages for removing NAs
param.help: If set to YES, NAs removed will be displayed for each group variable. Default is NO.

param.name: missingness
param.label: Percentage missing values in a group
param.help: Allowed missing values in a column to allow a user decide whether to remove the individual columns or rows from the data sets. Default 0.1. Therefore, if a column has more than 10 % missing values, then it will be removed from the dataset rather than the rows.

param.name: classify_or_autoremove
param.label: Either use outlier classification or autoremoval with threshold or LOESS method
param.help: The parameter allows to switch from outlification that labels all records as perfect outlier to fair outliers to allows further scrutiny. Otherwise, the outliers will be dropped based on a threshold set naively or using LOESS method.

param.name: bool_loess
param.label: Data extraction parameter: LOESS
param.help: If set to true then the local regression method for data extraction will be used

param.name: threshold_clean
param.label: Data extraction parameter: Threshold setting
param.help: If Data extraction parameter: LOESS is NO, then a threshold value can be provided. Default is 0.8. The threshold will significantly determine which is flagged as an absolute outlier.

param.name: outlierweights_mode
param.label: Data extraction parameter: Outlier weighting
param.help: Outlier weighting and selection methods. abs uses record proportional to identify an absolute outlier. Default is abs

param.name: classifymode
param.label: Cuts data into classess
param.help: Categorize data base on the correlation coefficient manner based on Akoglu 2018

param.name: eif_bool
param.label: Emprical Influence Function
param.help: Computes the Emprical Influence Function for classified outliers. Default is NO

tool.help: Use the dropdown menu at the top to select the OGC API processes hosted on https://aquainfra.ogc.igb-berlin.de/pygeoapi/ and then complete the corresponding form to run the service.
